extendedIngredients.name: asian fish sauce
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 tbsp. Korean anchovy sauce (aek jeot) or Southeast Asian fish sauce

extendedIngredients.name: cabbages
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 medium-size Napa cabbages, quartered lengthwise with core left intact, outer leaves discarded
metaInformation: with core left intact, outer leaves discarded

extendedIngredients.name: daikon
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 1⁄2 lb. daikon radishes, peeled and julienned

extendedIngredients.name: garlic
extendedIngredients.originalString: 14 cloves garlic, finely chopped and mashed into a paste

extendedIngredients.name: chives
extendedIngredients.originalString: 30 Korean chives or garlic chives, cut into 1" pieces

extendedIngredients.name: ginger
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 (2") pieces ginger, peeled, finely chopped, and mashed into a paste

extendedIngredients.name: chile powder
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup plus 2 tbsp. Korean chile powder

extendedIngredients.name: scallions
extendedIngredients.originalString: 10 scallions, white and light green parts only, thinly sliced diagonally

extendedIngredients.name: shrimp
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 1⁄2 tbsp. finely chopped Korean salted shrimp

extendedIngredients.name: watercress
extendedIngredients.originalString: 10 sprigs Korean watercress, trimmed and roughly chopped

winePairing.pairingText: Kimchi works really well with Chenin Blanc, Gewurztraminer, and Riesling. The best wine for Asian food depends on the cuisine and dish - of course - but these acidic whites pair with a number of traditional meals, spicy or not. The Essay Chenin Blanc with a 4.2 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 9 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Essay Chenin Blanc
productMatches.description: The Essay Chenin Blanc is a medium-bodied white blend made from South Africa's white varietal, Chenin Blanc. The Chenin Blanc gives the wines its fruit salad, guava and melon aromas and a refreshing acidity. Some sur lie on the less for a few months adds to the complexity and body. A touch of aromatic Viognier complements the fruit structure with some floral hints. The wine is perfect on its own as an aperitif on the porch on a hot summer's day. Chenin Blanc pairs well with a wide range of foods, especially sushi, oysters, Asian curries, sweet-and-sour dishes, and summer salads.Blend: 87% Chenin Blanc, 13% Viognier
